title: ASX dips as Wisetech and resources sector plummet
text:
"WiseTech is using uniquely confusing accounting strategies to exaggerate growth and income," said analyst Anne Stevenson-Yang in a report titled The Illusion of Success.

She said the $10.6 billion company could have overstated its profits by 178 per cent, cumulatively, since the 2016 financial year.

"We have spent months analysing the company and concluded that WiseTech is manipulating its accounts to make growth and profit appear higher than they really are."

The response to the accusations was quick, with Wisetech shares thrown into a trading halt 40 minutes after the report was released, yet they had already done significant damage – shares in the company were down 10.2 per cent to $30.

Another sour point for the market was mining production updates for the September quarter and investors punished those companies that published underwhelming results.

Resource production stumbles

One such company was Northern Star Resources. The gold miner told the market its production was down almost 40,000 ounces compared with the previous three months and, on top of that, sales had slowed as well.

Following the update, shares in the company fell 8 per cent to $10.25. However, the 0.2 per cent downturn in gold prices to $US1487.84 an ounce could have contributed to Northern Star's muted session as well.

Other resource stocks on the wane included BHP Group and Rio Tinto.

BHP said the production of petroleum, copper, iron ore, metallurgical coal, energy coal, and nickel were all down on the previous period. The big miner's shares fell 3.3 per cent to $34.86 a share.

Rio, which released its production update on Wednesday, bore mixed analyst reactions to its report and skidded 2.9 per cent to $87.22.

"Output of bauxite, alumina and aluminium was all weaker than we had expected due to weather, maintenance and operational issues," said Macquarie Wealth Management, which revised its target price on Rio lower to $105.

UBS analysts, meantime, acknowledged Rio's quarter was improved, but still saw "some niggles".

Advertisement

On the other hand was South32, which boosted its share price by 1.6 per cent to $2.50 with double-digit increases in manganese and zinc production. Woodside Petroleum was also on the up on Thursday, with a 0.7 per cent lift to $32.12.

Gains were also seen in IOOF Holdings after the financial adviser secured a lower price for its purchase of Australia and New Zealand Bank's wealth pension and investment business, which would now only cost $825 million instead of $950 million.

The development reflected well on IOOF shares, which rose 10.9 per cent to $7.05. Yet the positive feelings did not follow through to ANZ as it dropped 0.8 per cent to $27.95.

Fellow major banks Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and National Australia Bank were also in the red. CBA was down 0.4 per cent to $80.11, Westpac fell 0.6 per cent to $29.08, and NAB slid 0.1 to $28.86

Buy-now-pay-later juggernaut Afterpay entered its second straight day of declines with a 5.7 per cent retreat to $31.98. Meanwhile, Nine Entertainment snapped its losing streak by increasing 2.5 per cent to $1.84.
description: The Australian sharemarket has broken its five-session streak of growth as one of the nation's most prominent technology stocks faced fraud accusations.
